questions.answer_description:
VTP version 1 and version 2 support VLANs 1 to 1000 only. Extended-range VLANs are supported only in VTP version 3. If converting from VTP version 3 to VTP version 2, VLANs in the range 1006 to 4094 are removed from VTP control.
Reference: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/docs/switches/lan/catalyst6500/ios/12.2SX/configuration/guide/vtp.html

discussion.content: correct A transparent
It is A

Answer is Transparent . 
In VTP versions 1 and 2, the switch must be in VTP transparent mode when you create extended-range VLANs. VTP version 3 also supports creating extended-range VLANs in client or server mode. See the "Configuring Extended-Range VLANs" section on page 13-10.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/lan/catalyst3560/software/release/12-2_52_se/configuration/guide/3560scg/swvtp.html
You can create, modify, and delete VLANs on a switch in VTP transparent mode. In VTP versions 1 and 2, the switch must be in VTP transparent mode when you create extended-range VLANs.
I also think correct answer is C
Correct Answer is Transparent

It should be A - transparent mode.
I've verified it in my virtual lab (EVE-NG with L2 images) - I successfully added VLAN 2000 on the switch with VTPv2 and in transparent mode.

the Question is : "Which VTP mode is needed to configure an extended ...."

questions.question_text: Which VTP mode is needed to configure an extended VLAN, when a switch is configured to use VTP versions 1 or 2?

choices.D: Extended VLANs are only supported in version 3 and not in versions 1 or 2.

questions.answer_description: In this case, the port has been configured both as a trunk and as a switchport in data vlan 10. Obviously, a port can not be both, so even though Cisco IOS will accept both, the port will actually be used as a trunk, ignoring the switchport access VLAN 10 command.

discussion.content:
Correct answer is A. 

With the configuration shown, answer B will appear IF Gig1/0/1 is in a down state. In this question, Gig1/0/1 must be in an "up, line protocol is up (connected)" state, making A the correct answer. I verified the both results in a test lab environment.
the correct answer is A. no doubt
It is B

Obviously, correct answer is A.
It was verified by me in the lab.
I can verify that the answer is A. I have configured this on a lab switch and the output matches A.
There is not interface Gig1/0/1 in the answer A.. I think answer should be B as well.

Although the interface is configured in trunk mode and the correct explanation, the right answer is B. See the example below using a Catalyst 3550:

!
interface FastEthernet0/10
 switchport access vlan 10
 switchport trunk encapsulation dot1q
 switchport mode trunk
 switchport voice vlan 11
 spanning-tree portfast
!

VLAN Name Status Ports
---- -------------------------------- --------- -------------------------------
1 default active Fa0/5, Fa0/6, Fa0/7, Fa0/8, Fa0/9, Fa0/11, Fa0/12, Fa0/13, Fa0/14, Fa0/16
 Fa0/17, Fa0/18, Fa0/19, Fa0/20, Fa0/21, Fa0/22, Fa0/23, Gi0/1, Gi0/2
10 Data active Fa0/10
11 Voice active Fa0/10

"VTP pruning does not prune traffic from VLANs that are pruning-ineligible. VLAN 1 and VLANs 1002 to 1005 are always pruning-ineligible; traffic from these VLANs cannot be pruned. Extended-range VLANs (VLAN IDs greater than 1005) are also pruning-ineligible."

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/lan-switching/vtp/10558-21.html#vtp_pruning

questions.answer_description:
VTP pruning should only be enabled on VTP servers, all the clients in the VTP domain will automatically enable VTP pruning. By default, VLANs 2 1001 are pruning eligible, but VLAN 1 cant be pruned because its an administrative VLAN. Both VTP versions 1 and 2 supports pruning.
Reference: http://www.orbit-computer-solutions.com/VTP-Pruning.php
questions.question_text: Which VLAN range is eligible to be pruned when a network engineer enables VTP pruning on a switch?

questions.answer_description:
Cisco Discovery Protocol (CDP) version 2 passes native VLAN information between Cisco switches. If you have a native VLAN mismatch, you will see CDP error messages on the console output.
Reference: http://www.ciscopress.com/articles/article.asp?p=29803&seqNum=3
questions.question_text: Which statement about using native VLANs to carry untagged frames is true?

discussion.content:
https://community.cisco.com/t5/other-network-architecture/what-is-the-difference-between-cdp-versions-1-and-2/m-p/193319/highlight/true#M71835

https://learningnetwork.cisco.com/thread/97803

choices.A: Cisco Discovery Protocol version 2 carries native VLAN information, but version 1 does not.
choices.D: Cisco Discovery Protocol version 3 carries native VLAN information, but versions 1 and 2 do not.
choices.B: Cisco Discovery Protocol version 1 carries native VLAN information, but version 2 does not.
choices.C: Cisco Discovery Protocol version 1 and version 2 carry native VLAN information.

questions.answer_description:
Cisco advocates the benefits of pruning VLANs in order to reduce unnecessary frame flooding. The "vtp pruning" command prunes VLANs automatically, which stops the inefficient flooding of frames where they are not needed.
Reference: http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/switches/catalyst-6500-series-switches/24330-185.html
questions.question_text: A network engineer must improve bandwidth and resource utilization on the switches by stopping the inefficient flooding of frames on trunk ports where the frames are not needed. Which Cisco IOS feature can be used to achieve this task?

discussion.content: Agreed VTP pruning is a actual feature opposed to just manually configuring pruning.
